awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Multiscale Approach to Understand Outflows During High-Mass Star Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Most stars in the Milky Way Galaxy are like our Sun, but there are also stars with masses up to 100 times higher. These high-mass stars output enormous amounts of energy and live only for a few million years before ending their life as a supernova. A major challenge in astrophysics is to understand how these stars are formed. The investigators will use the National Science Foundation's large radio telescopes to observe young high-mass stars, which are still growing as surrounding matter falls onto them. During this process some of the matter is expelled in the form of jets and outflows of hot gas. To make progress in our scientific understanding of high-mass star formation, the next step is understanding the flow of material near these stars. A systematic study of outflows and jets is thus urgently needed. With these radio telescopes, the investigators will chart the flow of matter near these stars. Specifically, the investigators will make new observations every few months and map the motion of the clumps of material over time. The project is a collaboration between a primarily Hispanic serving university in New Mexico and a primarily undergraduate institution in rural Illinois. Student involvement in the planned observations provide hands-on STEM education on a variety of educational levels. Students will also take part in institutional interchanges and public outreach activities lead by the principal investigators. This project will thereby promote the participation of women and minorities in science.

Ionized jets and molecular outflows are commonly present in high-mass proto-stars. This project will carry out a multiscale observational study which addresses fundamental unanswered questions on the physics of the mass outflows. The goals of the project are 1) to connect the ionized jets to the large scale molecular flows with high quality measurements of the momentum rates, 2) to directly measure the ionized jet motion via proper motion and spectral line observations, and 3) to use water and methanol maser observations to study the jet launching mechanism, as well as the momentum transfer between ionized and molecular gas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled the principal investigators from two institutions, New Mexico Tech (a research-focused university located in a predominately Hispanic town in rural New Mexico), and Western Illinois University (a primarily undergraduate institution that mostly serves students from the rural midwest and the Chicago area) to join efforts to 1) increase our understanding of the formation process of high-mass stars, which are stars that explode as supernovae at the end of their lives and create heavy elements such as calcium and iron, and 2) contribute to the broader impacts of science in our society by offering a wide range of educational and outreach activities to benefit participants from elementary school children to doctoral students. In addition to outreach activities intended for children and the general public, the co-investigators of this project mentored middle school, high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in different sub-projects intended to understand phenomena associated with jets and outflows generated during the formation of high-mass stars. The results of the work were documented in scientific publications and presented at international, national and local conferences. Students were guided on how to conduct research as well as to prepare and deliver presentations at many venues, from middle school science fairs in rural Illinois to a scientific contribution by a doctoral student at the prestigious Protostars and Planets VII conference in Japan. Many different regions of high-mass star formation were investigated in this project using very powerful radio telescopes, such as the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in New Mexico. These telescopes detect microwaves to reveal the secrets inside giant clouds of dust and gas, which are completely opaque to visible light. In this project, we used the telescopes to investigate very hot ionized gas as well as clouds containing organic molecules such as methanol, and inorganic molecules such as water and ammonia. Among the many outcomes documented in our scientific publications and presentations, we discovered a narrow jet of molecular gas traced by hydroxyl molecules that is piercing its way out of a region where new stars are forming. We also developed a technique to reveal hidden molecules in datasets that were originally obtained to investigate hot ionized gas, and follow-up observations of some of the sources identified with our technique indicate that such hidden molecules can reveal rotation of gas around the young forming stars, and thus, show us how these young high-mass objects acquire material from their environment. We have studied a special type of radiation from molecules, known as masers (the analogous of lasers but at microwave wavelengths). Masers show frequent changes and give us a window into the dynamical nature of processes in space. Our observations of ionized gas have helped us quantify how strongly expanding jets push against their surroundings. As expected from a successful scientific project, the outcome of this work goes beyond the publications and discoveries produced during the years the work was directly supported by the NSF, but on the follow-up scientific questions that the data are bringing us and that are guiding the next research steps. The data generated in this project have a very important legacy value, as future studies on the time evolution of the regions will be possible by comparing new observations with the products of this research. But most importantly, the fundamental legacy of this project is in the outreach, training and research experiences provided to so many participants, including students who have now embarked on their own scientific journey, from a high-school student becoming a STEM major in college, to a doctoral student becoming a prestigious postdoctoral fellow.


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Esteban D Araya
